title: Are West Africans related to ancient Egyptians? - Quora

response.answer_text: All current humans are closely related, more so than those alive in 300,000 BC, i.e. current “races” evolved later. Precisely when enough mutations occurred for someone to exist as recognizable as today’s Bantu-type is unknown, but they are thought to have begun in west-central Africa. Likewise while DNA tests show that ancient Egypt was mostly not sub-Saharans but the same group that lived in Lebanon and southern Anatolia, we don’t know when such DNA group came to exist, nor even where (it is assumed West Asia). There are hypothesized dates for splits in the Homo Sapiens family tree and hypothesized places of origin; that is all. Between 300,000 BC and 40,000 BC is largely a blank to be filled in. But if you are asking are Egyptians without known sub-Saharan DNA still more closely related to West Africans than, say, a Swede or a Korean? Yes since the world has a falling cline of relationships across geographic space since people mate with neighbors even when they don’t have many to mate with, i.e. some end up having sex, and someone even earlier did, so Europeans and Native Americans have a common ancestor in Siberia, e.g. You can find “genetic distance” charts online for any two groups you want. It also can change over time, since e.g. the Levant was closer to Europe than to the Sinai before the spread of Islam, and sub-Saharan DNA increased in Egypt in the last 1500 years.

No. Ancient Egyptians carried Eurasian MTDNA and Haplogroup J and E-M78. None of the Haplogroups are found in West Africa. Haplogroup E-M78 originated in ancient Egypt 23 000 years ago. As you can see, West Africans got NONE:  Ancient Egyptians carried Haplogroup J from a migration of the ancient Middle Eastern Farmers. Haplogroup J originated in the Middle East 48 000 years ago and is the main Y-DNA of modern Copts. At least two mummies at Abusir el Meleq carried Haplogroup J. West Africans carry NO Haplogroup J  Ancient Egyptians carried the descendants of MTDNA N and as you can see, West Africans got none:  Modern and ancient Egyptian MTDNA:  Relatives of the ancient Egyptians:  West Africans carry Haplogroup E1B1A which originated in Ethiopia 42 000 years ago:  Haplogroup E-V38 - Wikipedia West Africans carry Sub saharan African MTDNA which originated in Sub Saharan Africa:

I find it interesting how Asia is allowed to have an ancient identity, Europe is allowed to and so is the “middle east” but in certain people’s minds, Africa isn’t. One thing recent population genetics has accomplished is debunking the tired trope that the populations in east/west and north/south Africa are somehow separated. They are not. They are culturally, linguistically and genetically linked. All indigenous Africans are related through the the PN2 transition of the Y chromosome So, since the populations of Kemet were Saharan and Nilotic, this would include them.  Here is the academic source: ".. there are male lineage ties between African peoples who have been traditionally labeled as being ‘‘racially’’ different, with ‘‘racially’’ implying an ontologically deep divide. The PN2 transition, a Y chromosome marker, defines a lineage (within the YAPþ derived haplogroup E or III) that emerged in Africa probably before the last glacial maximum, but after the migration of modern humans from Africa (see Semino et al., 2004). This mutation forms a clade that has two daughter subclades (defined by the biallelic markers M35/215 (or 215/M35) and M2) that unites numerous phenotypically variant African populations from the supra-Saharan, Saharan, and sub-Saharan regions.." (S.O.Y Keita. Exploring northeast African metric craniofacial variation at the individual level: A comparative study using principal component analysis. Am. J. Hum. Biol. 16:679–689, 2004.)

NO, Who writes these questions? They are different people racially and genetically. They look different and have totally different history.   The Egyptians had more in common with Eurasians and other Mediterraneans    Ancient Egyptians from the old, middle and new kingdom looked middle-eastern. Ancient Egyptians who look a lot like modern Egyptians.

No. West/sub saharan Africans are not related to North Africans. They have different components.. they dont cluster. North Africa shares ties with west Asia and Southern Europe/the mediterranean and not with the populations below the sahara desert(except East Africa to a certain degree=E-V32 but not totally either). To be continued
All humans are related but ancient egyptians are probably more related to everyone else.
Yes there’s a great possibility that West Africans are related to ancient Egyptians.
